sn44.10:4.1: Then the wanderer Vacchagotta went up to the Buddha
sn44.10:4.3: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side,
sn44.10:4.5: “Master Gotama, does the self exist absolutely?”
sn44.10:4.6: But when he said this, the Buddha kept silent.
sn44.10:4.7: “Then does the self not exist absolutely?”
sn44.10:4.8: But for a second time the Buddha kept silent.
sn44.10:4.9: Then the wanderer Vacchagotta got up from his seat and left.
sn44.10:5.1: And then, not long after Vacchagotta had left, Venerable Ānanda said to the Buddha:
sn44.10:5.2: “Sir, why didn’t you answer Vacchagotta’s question?”
sn44.10:5.3: “Ānanda, when Vacchagotta asked me whether the self exists absolutely, if I had answered that ‘the self exists absolutely’ I would have been siding with the ascetics and brahmins who are eternalists.
sn44.10:5.4: When Vacchagotta asked me whether the self does not exist absolutely, if I had answered that ‘the self does not exist absolutely’ I would have been siding with the ascetics and brahmins who are annihilationists.
sn44.10:5.5: When Vacchagotta asked me whether the self exists absolutely, if I had answered that ‘the self exists absolutely’ would that have helped give rise to the knowledge that
sn44.10:5.8: “When Vacchagotta asked me whether the self does not exist absolutely, if I had answered that ‘the self does not exist absolutely’, Vacchagotta—who is already confused—would have got even more confused, thinking:
sn44.10:5.9: ‘It seems that the self that I once had no longer exists.’”
